message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Nitrofurantoin is safe to use in pregnancy and is effective at treating UTIs caused by E. coli. Since the patient has had a previous UTI, prophylaxis with nitrofurantoin for the rest of the pregnancy is appropriate to prevent recurrence. Cephalexin is also safe to use in pregnancy but nitrofurantoin is the preferred first-line agent for UTIs in pregnancy. IV antibiotic prophylaxis is not necessary in this case.

We refer to UpToDate for help. Pregnant women with UTIs should be treated with antibiotics, and nitrofurantoin is a safe option during pregnancy. However, because this patient has had a recent UTI, she is at risk for recurrent infections, and it is recommended to continue prophylactic treatment with nitrofurantoin for the rest of the pregnancy to prevent another infection. Cephalexin is also safe during pregnancy but does not have prophylactic properties for preventing recurrent UTIs. IV antibiotic prophylaxis is not necessary for this patient.

We refer to MedlinePlus articles on urinary tract infections for help. Nitrofurantoin is safe for treatment of UTIs during pregnancy and can also be used for prophylaxis to prevent recurrence. Cephalexin is also safe but does not have prophylactic properties. IV antibiotic prophylaxis is not necessary for uncomplicated UTIs. Therefore, the most appropriate management would be to treat the current UTI with Nitrofurantoin and continue prophylaxis with Nitrofurantoin for the rest of the pregnancy to prevent recurrence.

We refer to UpToDate for help. Nitrofurantoin is appropriate for treating UTIs in pregnancy. Since the patient had a previous UTI, prophylactic treatment with nitrofurantoin for the rest of the pregnancy is appropriate. Cephalexin is also an option for UTIs but it's not necessary to administer IV antibiotic prophylaxis for the rest of the pregnancy.

We refer to UpToDate for help. Nitrofurantoin is a commonly used antibiotic for UTIs during pregnancy, and since this patient had a similar UTI 7 weeks ago that was resolved with appropriate medication, treatment with nitrofurantoin and continuation of nitrofurantoin prophylaxis for the rest of the pregnancy would be the most appropriate management. Cephalexin is also an option for UTI treatment in pregnancy, but there is no indication for IV antibiotic prophylaxis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is pregnant and has a history of UTI, which increases the risk for recurrent UTI. Nitrofurantoin is safe for use during pregnancy and is the first-line treatment for uncomplicated UTI in pregnancy. Continuing with nitrofurantoin prophylaxis for the rest of the pregnancy can also help prevent recurrent UTIs. Cephalexin is another option but is not the first-line treatment for UTI in pregnancy. IV antibiotic prophylaxis for the rest of the pregnancy is not necessary unless the patient develops pyelonephritis.

We refer to UpToDate for help. Nitrofurantoin is the first-line agent for treating UTIs in pregnancy. Given the patient's history of recurrent UTIs during pregnancy, continuing with nitrofurantoin prophylaxis for the rest of the pregnancy is the most appropriate management. Cephalexin is an alternative agent but IV antibiotic prophylaxis is not necessary.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Nitrofurantoin is safe to use during pregnancy, and prophylactic treatment may be necessary as the patient has had recurrent UTIs. Cephalexin is also an option, but it does not cover gram-negative bacteria like E. coli as well as nitrofurantoin. IV antibiotic prophylaxis for the rest of the pregnancy is not necessary as the patient is only experiencing a UTI and does not have any other indicators of serious infection.

We refer to medicine textbooks for help. The patient has a repeat UTI with a high bacterial count, indicating a recurrent infection. Nitrofurantoin is the drug of choice for pregnant women with UTIs, and continuation of prophylaxis for the rest of the pregnancy can prevent further recurrences. Cephalexin can also be used but nitrofurantoin is preferred due to its safety profile in pregnancy. IV antibiotic prophylaxis is not necessary in this case.

We refer to UpToDate articles on medicine for help. Nitrofurantoin is the first line treatment for uncomplicated UTIs in pregnancy. Due to the recurrence of the UTI, it is appropriate to continue with nitrofurantoin prophylaxis for the rest of the pregnancy to prevent further episodes. Cephalexin and IV antibiotic prophylaxis are not indicated or necessary in this case, as the first-line treatment of nitrofurantoin is effective in most uncomplicated UTIs.
